questions.promptMd: Rank the following from strongest to weakest proof in most B2B cases: A) audited third‑party review, B) pilot results, C) internal opinion, D) peer reference call.

answers.feedbackMd: Peer references are strong but usually below independent audits.
Pilots are solid but typically below audits/references.
References are often stronger than a single pilot due to external credibility.

questions.promptMd: True or False: Relevance (same industry, role, and scale) can outweigh sheer quantity of weaker proofs.

answers.feedbackMd: Correct. Highly relevant proofs transfer more belief.
Quantity of weak proof rarely beats a few strong, relevant proofs.

questions.promptMd: Which sequence BEST layers a proof stack?

answers.contentMd: Independent audit → peer reference → pilot results → internal data
answers.feedbackMd: Strongest first, then triangulate with context and internal metrics.

answers.contentMd: Internal opinion → pilot results → peer reference → audit
answers.feedbackMd: Leads weak, buries the strongest at the end.

answers.contentMd: Peer reference → internal opinion → pilot → audit
answers.feedbackMd: Opinion adds little; audit shouldn’t be last.

questions.promptMd: True or False: Logo walls are sufficient when the audience is technical and risk‑sensitive.

answers.feedbackMd: Logos without outcomes rarely persuade technical, risk‑sensitive audiences.
Correct. Provide outcomes and references, not just logos.
